newsitem.title: USA: Philip Morris posts 15 percent profit rise.
newsitem.headline: Philip Morris posts 15 percent profit rise.

text.p: Philip Morris Cos Inc. said Tuesday that increased cigarette sales worldwide and improvements in its North American food businesses pushed its profits up by 15 percent in the third quarter.

The company, whose products include Marlboro cigarettes, Miller beer and Maxwell House coffee, said its net income for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose to $1.65 billion, or $2.01 a share, from $1.43 billion, or $1.71 a share.
It said revenues grew by 4.3 percent to $17.4 billion from $16.7 billion.
Philip Morris said its profit and revenue comparisons did not include North American food businesses sold since the start of last year.

"Philip Morris hit another home run in the quarter," Chairman Geoffrey C. Bible said in a statement accompanying the results. "Our three largest businesses are absolutely flying, with terrific momentum in both domestic and international tobacco, and growth in North American food that is clearly outstanding by industry standards."

The company, whose cigarette products include Merit, Benson & Hedges, Parliament and Virginia Slims, said tobacco income grew 13 percent, primarily on increased sales of premium-priced cigarettes like Marlboro and Benson & Hedges.
Worldwide tobacco revenues grew 12.6 percent to $9.5 billion as Philip Morris sold 238 billion cigarettes, an increase of 9.3 percent.
Marlboro continued to build on its position as the best-selling cigarette in the world, the company said.
Philip Morris, whose food brands include Kraft, Oscar Mayer, Del Monte, Kool-Aid and Jell-O, said its North American food revenues grew 4 percent, excluding divestitures.
It said a 9 percent increase in food income was fuelled by double-digit gains in beverages, pizza and desserts, along with solid increases in coffee, cereals, and processed meats.
However, Philip Morris said beer revenues fell 3.9 percent to $1.1 billion on lower volume.
Higher worldwide cigarette sales and North American food volume gains also drove up profits for the first nine months, the company said.
Net income for the period rose 16 percent to $4.83 billion, or $5.87 a share, from $4.18 billion, or $4.95 a share, as revenues expanded by 4 percent to $52.4 billion from $50.3 billion.
The company said tobacco revenues in the period grew by 13 percent to $27.8 billion from $24.7 billion while food revenues declined due to the sale of several subsidiaries.
Philip Morris stock slipped 87.5 cents to $92.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
